N-oxides represent a significant class of compounds with increasing value due to their extensive applications in chemistry and biology. Herein, a series of heterogeneous catalysts were prepared based on the impregnation-precipitation method. In this strategy, protonated graphitic carbon nitride (pg-C3N4) was prepared first, and Cs3PW12O40 was immobilized over the surface of pg-C3N4 to obtain CsPW-CN composites. The prepared CsPW-CN composites achieved better catalytic activities than the pure Cs3PW12O40 in the N-oxidation of pyridine, and obtained 99% yield of pyridine-N-oxide in aqueous medium with H2O2 as a mild oxidant. Based on the characterizations of the catalyst morphology, structure, and chemical composition, the intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 was verified. Meanwhile, the occurrence of the unique semi-embedded structure was an expected derivation of the pg-C3N4. Furthermore, the prepared CsPW-CN-1 composite was readily recovered and yielded 88.3% of the pyridine-N-oxide after 4 runs. This work could potentially provide a well-defined CsPW-CN composite for the N-oxidation of pyridine with a sustainable approach. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polyoxometalates Graphitic carbon nitride Catalytic oxidation Pyridine-N-oxides Introduction N-oxides of nitrogen heterocycles, especially pyridine-N-oxides, were of increasing importance. They were widely used as the intermediates for functionalization or structural modification of amides, and also the reagents for oxidation, protective groups and ligand-metal complexes 1 . Moreover, they were also promising precursors in drug filed 2 . Traditionally, N-oxides of nitrogen heterocycles were prepared by a non-catalytic oxidation process, which used dioxirane 3 , Caro's acid 4 , activated H2O2 5 , peracids 6 , α-azohydroperoxides 7 or magnesium monophthalate 8 as oxidants. Although these reagents cost little, they generated significant amounts of drainage, requiring a painstaking post-processing procedure. Consequently, an eco-friendly and efficient catalytic oxidation was highly desirable 9 . H2O2 was a hopeful oxidant in aqueous medium, which produced H2O as the only by-product 10 . Several catalytic N-oxidation systems using H2O2 had received much attention, such as AcOH/H2O2 11 , MeReO3/H2O2 12 , trifluoroacetic anhydride/H2O2 13 , and triflic anhydride/Na2CO3•1.5H2O2 14 . However, these homogenous catalysts suffered from many defects such as their unrecyclable property and low atom effectiveness, which hindered their applications. In order to break through these limits, heterogeneous catalysts including VxSi4xO6.4x 15 , titanium silicalite-1 16 , vanadium-silicate molecular sieve material 17 , titanium molecular sieve 18 , perfluoroketone-silicate 19 , Ru/Al2O3 20 and tungstate-exchanged layered double hydroxide (LDH-WO4) 21 had been applied in the N-oxidation reaction with H2O2 as oxidant. However, issues such as long reaction time, excess oxidants, and poisonous solvents were frequently presented under those heterogeneous catalytic systems. In this context, it's essential to experimentally develop an eco-friendly, recyclable and efficient heterogeneous catalytic systems to further improve the N-oxidation process of nitrogen heterocycles. Polyoxometalates (POMs) as one of molecular metal-oxygen clusters had attracted considerable interests due to their high efficiency during the catalytic oxidation of organic substrates 22 . Furthermore, their thermal and oxidative stability and chem-physical properties could be modulated by selecting elemental composition 23 . Recently, it was reported that K6[PW9V3O40] 24 , Δ-Na8HPW9O34 25 , K8[BW11O39H] 26 , K8[γ-SiW11O39] 27 , and {Mo132} 28 had high catalytic activities for the N-oxidation of nitrogen heterocycles. Although the N-oxidation catalyzed by POMs was effective, it was difficult to isolate and regenerate POMs due to their high solubility in polar solvents, which greatly limited POMs’ further applications 29 . To overcome these problems, different methods for immobilizing POMs were proposed, including electrostatic interaction 30 , metal-ligand coordination 31 , covalent modification 32 , and encapsulation 33 . Unfortunately, resources on heterogeneous catalysts using POMs as active component for the N-oxidation reaction were scarce. On the other hand, the carrier played an important role in the preparation and application of heterogeneous catalysts 34 . In recent years, g-C3N4 had attracted much attention in the field of multiphase catalysis due to its electrical conductivity and two-dimensional planar layers 35 . Also, protonated graphitic carbon nitride (pg-C3N4), a derivative of g-C3N4, could offer potential anchor sites for the immobilization of POMs 36 . Moreover, compared with g-C3N4, pg-C3N4 was better at charge transport, which improved the interaction between POMs and pg-C3N4 36 , 37 . In this work, we first used protons to modify the g-C3N4 and successfully achieved the protonation of g-C3N4. Subsequently, H3PW12O40 was added to aqueous medium with pg-C3N4 as the carrier and stirred magnetically. After that, Cs3PW12O40 was immobilized on the pg-C3N4 by the addition of excess Cs+ solution, followed by hydrothermal reaction, and a series of heterogeneous catalysts were prepared. In subsequent studies, we found out that the uniform size of Cs3PW12O40 decorated on pg-C3N4 was responsible for making CsPW-CN an efficient catalyst in N-oxidation of pyridine in liquid phase. As we verified, the intimate interaction between pg-C3N4 and Cs3PW12O40 was essential for CsPW-CN composites, guaranteeing the high catalytic efficiency and well stability of CsPW-CN under the optimized reaction conditions. Moreover, FT-IR, XRD, XPS, SEM, TEM, TGA, 31P NMR and N2 adsorption-desorption were further employed to study the intrinsic correlations between the excellent catalytic properties and the catalyst structure. The developed heterogeneous system could potentially provide a promising solution for the practical catalysis application of N-oxidation reaction. Experimental section General Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were obtained by a Nexus 670 spectrometer equipped with KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000 cm−1. X-ray-diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku D/MAX 2550 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer using Al Kα radiation at 1486.6 eV, and the binding energies were calibrated with the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was performed on a Hitachi SU-8010 microscope and energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) combined with FESEM was applied for elemental distribution mappings. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) were utilized to observe the catalysts’ morphology on a FEI Talos F200S with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was measured with a TGA/DSC3+ analyzer made by Mettler Toledo Corp., and the experimental temperature ranged from 20 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C•min−1 in air. Inductively coupled plasma was applied to measure the content of W (ICP-OES, Optima 2100DV). The solide-state 31P NMR spectrum of the catalyst was recorded on Bruker Avance III HD. The specific surface areas and pore volume distributions were calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) respectively from N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K determined by a Micromeritics 3Flex (Micromeritics instrument Ltd.). Catalyst preparation All chemicals were bought from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd without further purification. The g-C3N4 was synthesized based on a modified method 38 . Briefly, 2.0 g of melamine, 3.0 g of ammonium chloride and 0.02 g of polyvinyl pyrrolidone (K-30) were mixed and grounded for 10 mins, followed by calcining at 550 °C for 4 h. Then, the light yellow product was obtained and grounded into a fine powder. The pg-C3N4 was prepared by the protonation of g-C3N4 with ultrasonic-assisted dispersion 39 . Typically, 4.0 g of g-C3N4 was dispersed in 80 mL of 37 wt% HCl, followed by sonicating for 2 h and vigorously stirring for 15 h at room temperature. Then, the resulting suspension was filtered and washed to neutral with deionized water, followed by drying at 60 °C to a constant weight. The CsPW-CN composites were prepared based on the impregnation-precipitation method. Briefly, 0.3 g of pg-C3N4 was dispersed in 50 mL of deionized water, followed by sonicating for 2 h and vigorously stirring for another 1 h at the room temperature. Subsequently, a certain volume of 0.1 g/mL H3PW12O40 solution (300 μL, 600 μL, 900 μL, respectively) was added into the above suspension, followed by stirring for 5 h first, and then adding corresponding volume of 0.1 g/mL Cs2CO3 solution (100 μL, 200 μL, 300 μL, respectively), and finally stirring for another 1 h. In particular, the molar ratio of Cs+/PW12O40 3− was 5.9. At last, the obtained suspension was transferred into a 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave to undergo a hydrothermal reaction at 150 °C for 15 h. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was collected and washed with deionized water for several times, and then dried at 80 °C overnight to yield the corresponding composites with different contents of Cs3PW12O40 (CsPW-CN-1, CsPW-CN-2, CsPW-CN-3, respectively). In comparison, the pure Cs3PW12O40 was also prepared via the same synthetic route. Activity tests The N-oxidation reaction of pyridine was carried out in a regular glass reactor with oil bath and magnetic stirrer. In a typical experiment, 20 mg of catalyst and 1 mmol of pyridine were added to 1 mL of deionized water under continuous stirring. After the temperature was heated to 60 °C, 3 mmol of hydrogen peroxide (30 wt% aq. solution) was added dropwise. When the reaction was finished and cooled to the room temperature, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, and the collected liquid phase was then analyzed by using a liquid chromatography (LC, Agilent 2200) with water and methanol (9:11) as mobile phase. The solid catalyst was washed with deionized water, followed by drying at 80 °C overnight in vacuum for future catalytic usages. In addition, a series of experiments were carried out to optimize reaction conditions such as catalyst amounts, hydrogen peroxide dosage, reaction time, etc.. Results and discussion Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 showed the XRD patterns of the pure Cs3PW12O40, CsPW-CN-1, CsPW-CN-2, CsPW-CN-3 and pg-C3N4. As for g-C3N4 (Fig. S2), the Jade analysis results confirmed that there were characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 13°and 27.4°, which were indexed as (100) and (002) planes, i.e. the in-plane structural packing motif and interplanar stacking structure of graphitic crystal, respectively 40 . Furthermore, Fig. S2 showed that the (002) diffraction peak of pg-C3N4 shifted to a higher angle of 27.8° and the (002) diffraction peak's interplanar distance of d value changed from 0.325 nm (g-C3N4) to 0.319 nm (pg-C3N4), indicating tighter packing in the pg-C3N4 nanosheets. Meanwhile, the (100) diffraction peak became inconspicuous and shifted to a lower angle of 12.8°, demonstrating the decreasing plane size and the increasingly stretched properties of pg-C3N4 39 . Undoubtably, these changes indicated the success of protonation of g-C3N4 39 , 41 . Overall, the crystal structure of g-C3N4 after protonation continued substantially to be the same apart from some minor changes. As shown in Fig. 1, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the pure Cs3PW12O40 appeared at 2θ = 18.3, 23.6, 26.1, 30.1°, corresponding to the (211), (310), (222) and (400) crystallographic planes of the cubic phase (JCPDS 50–1857), as described as early works 42 , 43 . For CsPW-CN composites in Fig. 1, the corresponding results suggested the coexistence of pg-C3N4 and Cs3PW12O40. Additionally, the intensities of diffraction peaks of pg-C3N4 decreased gradually with increasing contents of Cs3PW12O40 in the CsPW-CN composites, indicating the decrease of crystallinity (pg-C3N4). According to these phenomena, Cs3PW12O40 nanocrystals might embed into the interlayers of pg-C3N4 and disturb the uniform structure of the pg-C3N4, which led to the gradual changes of the diffraction peaks of pg-C3N4 44 . These results provided evidence that there was an intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 45 . For the purpose of analyzing the chemical function of pg-C3N4, g-C3N4 and CsPW-CN composites, FT-IR spectra were performed, as shown in Fig. 2 . By contrast, FT-IR spectra of g-C3N4 were similar to that of pg-C3N4, indicating that the chemical structure of g-C3N4 remained roughly the same after protonation. For g-C3N4 (Fig. 2a), the multiple bands in the range of 1243–1638 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of C = N bond, CN bond on aromatic CN heterocyclic ring and CN bond outside the ring, and the sharp peak at 808 cm−1 could be attributed to the bending vibration of tri-s-triazine 46 . As for the broad adsorption bands of g-C3N4 in the scope of 3000–3500 cm−1, they could be attributed to the uncondensed amino function groups and the OH bond of the absorbed water 47 . Furthermore, compared with the FT-IR spectrum of g-C3N4, the multiple bands of pg-C3N4 in the scope of 1243–1638 cm−1 variated significantly. The peaks at 1638 cm−1 and 1456 cm−1 (assigned to CN and C = N, respectively) shifted to 1628 cm−1 and 1462 cm−1, respectively; the peak at 1570 cm−1 for pg-C3N4 corresponding to C = N in aromatic CN heterocycles nearly disappeared for the pg-C3N4. Those changes were all associated with the successful protonation of g-C3N4 48 . As shown in Fig. 2b, the characteristic peaks of the Keggin unit PW12O40 3− were observed at 810, 889, 989 and 1080 cm−1 and could be assigned to the vibrations of W-Oc-W, W-Ob-W, W=Od and P-Oa, respectively, according to early studies 49 . In addition, the peak of pg-C3N4 at 808 cm−1 couldn't be observed in the FT-IR spectra of CsPW-CN composites due to the overlap of the FT-IR modes of Cs3PW12O40. Additionally, the four characteristic peaks of the PW12O40 3− were also clearly observed in the FT-IR spectra of CsPW-CN composites, suggesting the preservation of primary Keggin unit (PW12O40 3−) after the immobilization of Cs3PW12O40 over the surface of pg-C3N4 50 . Compared with that of Cs3PW12O40 at 700–1150 cm−1, the minor changes in wave numbers for CsPW-CN-3 were observed (Fig. S3), indicating the existence of intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 51 , which was consistent with the XRD analysis results. The morphology and microstructure of the CsPW-CN-1 and pg-C3N4 were studied with FESEM and TEM. In Fig. 3 a and 3b, it can be discovered that the obtained pg-C3N4 presented an obvious lamellar structure 52 , which could provide enough anchor sites for the active component. Also, we found out that pg-C3N4 had similar morphology compared to that of g-C3N4, as described in our early work 53 . In this study, the HRTEM (Fig. S6 and Fig. 3b) also revealed that the unorthodox pore structure of pg-C3N4 was mainly composed of disordered worm-like pores 54 . Fig. 3c-d and Fig. S5 displayed the TEM images of the CsPW-CN-1, suggesting the surface of pg-C3N4 support was decorated with uniform size of Cs3PW12O40 spherical nanoparticles (the yellow dashed lines represent the identified edges of Cs3PW12O40). Moreover, the semi-embedded structure was also observed between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4. It was suggested that the intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 might promote the formation of the unique microstructure. In Fig. 3e-i and Fig. S4, the elemental mappings revealed that P, W, O and Cs elements of CsPW-CN-1 composite were almost uniformly dispersed on the pg-C3N4, indicating the successful immobilization of Cs3PW12O40 on the surface of pg-C3N4. TGA was used to investigate the thermal stability of the catalysts and the roughly content of Cs3PW12O40 in the CsPW-CN composites. As depicted in Fig. 4 , pg-C3N4 went through a fast weight dropping phase starting from 550 °C to around 680 °C due to its combustion. Compared the TGA curve of pg-C3N4 to that of the CsPW-CN composites, it can be learned that the presence of Cs3PW12O40 reduced the thermal stability of pg-C3N4, making the pg-C3N4 become more conductive to burn 55 . Moreover, Keggin unit (PW12O40 3−) underwent decomposition in the scope of 500–560 °C, which was in accordance with the literature 56 . Furthermore, the W content of CsPW-CN-1 was analyzed by ICP-OES (Optima 2100DV) and the result was 6.6 wt%. Based on the weight residue of the composites, the ratio of the loading of catalysts was nearly 1:2:3, which was consistent with the theoretical ratio. In addition, the 31P NMR spectrum of CsPW-CN-1 composite was shown in Fig. S7. Compared to the chemical shift (−15 ppm) of phosphorus in Cs3PW12O40, the P signal in CsPW-CN-1 was slightly higher than that of Cs3PW12O40, indicating the existence of intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 43 , 57 . Such a change was also observed in other POMs-based materials 58 . XPS was further used to reveal the chemical state and surface components of CsPW-CN-1 composite. In Fig. S8, the wide-range XPS spectrum confirmed the existence of Cs, C, N, P, W and O elements in the CsPW-CN-1 composite undoubtably, which matched the EDS analysis results (Fig. 3f). In addition, the peak of P 2p spectrum was not obvious due to the low content of P element (Fig. S9). The C 1s spectrum in Fig. 5 a could be deconvoluted into three independent peaks at 284.6 eV, 286.1 eV and 288.1 eV, which were assigned to CC bonds, CN-C bonds, and NC = N bonds of the pg-C3N4 support, respectively 59 . Moreover, the high resolution N 1 s spectrum (Fig. 5b) of CsPW-CN-1 confirmed existences of sp2-hybridized nitrogen (N1, yellow) at 398.4 eV, the tertiary nitrogen (N(C)3, N2, purple) at 399.4 eV and the amino functional groups (N4, green) at 400.7 eV 59 . Besides, the peak at 404.8 eV was assigned to the positive charge position in aromatic CN heterocycles (N3, pink), suggesting that g-C3N4 was successfully protonated 60 . Fig. 5c revealed that the binding energies of O 1s peaks were situated at 531.6 eV and 530.3 eV, which were attributed to the terminal hydroxyl groups (-OH) on the surface and lattice oxygen atoms of Cs3PW12O40 61 . Moreover, combining with the results of FT-IR spectra, the amino functional group and the protonated nitrogen of pg-C3N4 made pg-C3N4 and Cs3PW12O40 interacted intimately with each other through hydrogen bond and coordination 35 , 39 , 62 . According to the W 4f spectrum (Fig. 5d), the peaks of binding energies of 37.6 eV and 35.5 eV were respectively ascribed to W 4f5/2 and W 4f7/2 doublets, revealing the existence of W + 6 in Keggin unit 63 . Additionally, the W 4f binding energies of CsPW-CN-1 clearly shifted to a lower position compared to that of Cs3PW12O40 (Fig. S10), indicating the existence of electron transfer between pg-C3N4 and Cs3PW12O40 44 . The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore size of pg-C3N4 and CsPW-CN-1 were measured and the results were shown in Fig. 6 . It could be clearly observed that type Ⅳ isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop was present in each sample, revealing the existence of mesopore. Besides, elaborated structural parameters were provided in Table 1 . It was worth noting that the surface area of CsPW-CN-1 (57.38 m2•g − 1) was larger than that of pg-C3N4(44.59 m2•g − 1). Such a phenomenon could be attributed to the well dispersion of Cs3PW12O40 over pg-C3N4 surface as well as the occurrence of piled pore or the slit hole, which further resulted in an increase of the surface areas of CsPW-CN-1 64 , 65 . Based on the XRD and TEM results, we thought the expansion of the interlayer was caused by the embedding of Cs3PW12O40 in the pg-C3N4 interlayer 64 . Similar phenomenon was also observed in other g-C3N4 derived materials 44 , 64 . NOxidation activity and catalyst stability The catalytic performance of the obtained CsPW-CN composites for the N-oxidation of pyridine to pyridine-N-oxide was recorded in Table 2 . The blank experiment showed that the yield of pyridine-N-oxide was 12.1% in the absence of the catalyst (Entry 1). Similarly, when pg-C3N4 was used, the yield of pyridine-N-oxide was only 23.6% (Entry 2). After the immobilization, the prepared CsPW-CN composites exhibited the distinct catalytic activities for the N-oxidation of pyridine in aqueous medium with hydrogen peroxide as a mild oxidant. For entry 4, 6 and 7, it was found that the yields of pyridine-N-oxide were similar, when using CsPW-CN-1, CsPW-CN-2 and CsPW-CN-3, respectively as the catalyst. This was due to the increase of Cs3PW12O40 loading, the phenomenon of serious agglomeration would occur inevitably, resulting in the decrease of the number of active sites. On the other hand, both the pure Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 showed relatively poor catalytic activities, which could possibly be evidences confirming the importance of intimate interactions between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4. Furthermore, CsPW-CN-1 as a representative catalyst was used to investigate the effects of distinct reaction parameters on the catalytic activity of the N-oxidation of pyridine and the relative results were shown in Fig. 7 and Fig. S12-S13. Since the N-oxidation of pyridine was endothermic, the yields of pyridine-N-oxide increased proportionally with temperature in the range of 40–80 °C (Fig. 7a). In more details, a satisfactory yield of 99% was achieved when the temperature was raised to 80 °C. In addition, the reaction time was another key factor affecting the yield of pyridine-N-oxide. In Fig. 7b, the yields increased constantly across the N-oxidation process but flattened off after 3 h, indicating that the catalytic activity of CsPW-CN-1 reached an equilibrium. Moreover, increasing the amount of catalyst could also influence the yields of pyridine-N-oxide as well. As shown in Fig. S12, a sharp increase in the yield of pyridine-N-oxide was observed when the catalyst dosage was boosted from 0 mg to 20 mg. Once the catalyst dosage increased to 25 mg, the yield of pyridine-N-oxide showed no further improvement. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. S13, with the increase of hydrogen peroxide dosages, the yield of pyridine-N-oxide increased significantly when the molar ratio of hydrogen peroxide to pyridine was less than 2.5. So far, as shown in Table 2, compared with other heterogeneous systems, the developed heterogeneous system uses nontoxic solvent and achieves a more efficient N-oxidation of pyridine with satisfactory yields of pyridine-N-oxide. To inspect the sustainability process, a series of recycling experiments using preferable CsPW-CN-1 catalyst were performed under the optimal reaction conditions. After each run, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water repetitiously, followed by drying at 80 °C overnight in vacuum for subsequent uses. It could be seen that the yield of pyridine-N-oxides decreased during those successive runs (Fig. 8 ). However, the yield of pyridine-N-oxide (88.3%) after 4 runs was still higher than that of most catalysts reported (Table 2). As shown in Fig. S11, the XRD pattern of CsPW-CN-1 after 4 runs was similar to that of the fresh CsPW-CN-1. Moreover, the hot filtration test was performed and CsPW-CN-1 was filtered out from the reaction mixture after 90-min-reaction. The corresponding results in Fig. S14 showed that the yield of pyridine-N-oxide increased slightly with the extension of the reaction time, which might be due to the slight leaching of the tungsten species, and the assumption was verified by ICP-OES (Optima 2100DV). Overall, CsPW-CN-1 demonstrated an excellent catalytic performance and a well stability, highlighting the application potential for N-oxidation of pyridine in a succeeding industrial scale. Conclusion In summary, a novel and efficient heterogeneous catalytic system for the N-oxidation of pyridine using hydrogen peroxide as oxidant in aqueous media was successfully developed. The prepared catalysts exhibited better catalytic activities than the pure Cs3PW12O40, and the highest pyridine-N-oxides yield achieved 99% within 3 h over CsPW-CN-1. The analyses of FT-IR and XRD revealed that pg-C3N4 was successfully prepared. Furthermore, the results of HRTEM confirmed that the semi-embedded catalyst with spherical Cs3PW12O40 decorated on pg-C3N4 as well as a clear integrated interface between them were formed. XPS analysis also suggested the existence of electron transfer between pg-C3N4 and Cs3PW12O40. Additionally, compared to other reported heterogeneous catalysts, the presented system offered a more promising and greener method to synthesize N-oxides. Text for table of contents In this work, different contents of Cs3PW12O40 decorated on protonated graphitic carbon nitride (CsPW-CN composites) were prepared based on the impregnation-precipitation method. And the intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and protonated graphitic carbon nitride was verified by various characterization techniques. The CsPW-CN composites achieved better catalytic activities than the pure Cs3PW12O40 in the N-oxidation of pyridine, and obtained 99% yield of pyridine-N-oxide in aqueous medium with H2O2 as a mild oxidant. Furthermore, the prepared CsPW-CN-1 was readily recovered, and yielded 88.3% of pyridine-N-oxide after 4 runs. This work provided a well-defined CsPW-CN composite for the N-oxidation of pyridine with a sustainable approach. coredata.dc:description: N-oxides represent a significant class of compounds with increasing value due to their extensive applications in chemistry and biology. Herein, a series of heterogeneous catalysts were prepared based on the impregnation-precipitation method. In this strategy, protonated graphitic carbon nitride (pg-C3N4) was prepared first, and Cs3PW12O40 was immobilized over the surface of pg-C3N4 to obtain CsPW-CN composites. The prepared CsPW-CN composites achieved better catalytic activities than the pure Cs3PW12O40 in the N-oxidation of pyridine, and obtained 99% yield of pyridine-N-oxide in aqueous medium with H2O2 as a mild oxidant. Based on the characterizations of the catalyst morphology, structure, and chemical composition, the intimate interaction between Cs3PW12O40 and pg-C3N4 was verified. Meanwhile, the occurrence of the unique semi-embedded structure was an expected derivation of the pg-C3N4. Furthermore, the prepared CsPW-CN-1 composite was readily recovered and yielded 88.3% of the pyridine-N-oxide after 4 runs. This work could potentially provide a well-defined CsPW-CN composite for the N-oxidation of pyridine with a sustainable approach.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilization of polyoxometalates on protonated graphitic carbon nitride: A highly efficient and reusable catalyst for the synthesis of pyridine-N-oxides
